passages.text: Fine-scale analysis of 16S rRNA sequences reveals a high level of taxonomic diversity among vaginal Atopobium spp.
Atopobium, vaginal microbiome, genetic diversity

Although vaginal microbial communities of some healthy women have high proportions of Atopobium vaginae, the genus Atopobium is more commonly associated with bacterial vaginosis, a syndrome associated with an increased risk of adverse pregnancy outcomes and the transmission of sexually transmitted diseases. Genetic differences within Atopobium species may explain why single species can be associated with both health and disease. We used 16S rRNA gene sequences from previously published studies to explore the taxonomic diversity of the genus Atopobium in vaginal microbial communities of healthy women. Although A. vaginae was the species most commonly found, we also observed three other Atopobium species in the vaginal microbiota, one of which, A. parvulum, was not previously known to reside in the human vagina. Furthermore, we found several potential novel species of the genus Atopobium and multiple phylogenetic clades of A. vaginae. The diversity of Atopobium found in our study, which focused only on samples from healthy women, is greater than previously recognized, suggesting that analysis of samples from women with BV would yield even more diversity. Classification of microbes only to the genus level may thus obfuscate differences that might be important to better understand health or disease.

Members of the genus Atopobium are commonly found in the vaginas of healthy asymptomatic women (Zhou et al.
2007; Yamamoto et al.
2009; Ravel et al.
2011). For example, in a cross-sectional study of 396 women from four ethnic groups, Atopobium was found to have a relative abundance of >1% in the vaginal bacterial communities in 93 women (Ravel et al.
2011). In these communities Atopobium contributes to the lactic acid present in the vagina that creates a low environmental pH that is thought to be important for the maintenance of vaginal health (Redondo-Lopez, Cook and Sobel 1990; Sobel 1999; Kumar et al.
2003; Zhou et al.
2010; Linhares et al.
2011; Hickey et al.
2012). However, members of the genus Atopobium along with Gardnerella, Megasphaera, Sneathia and Leptotrichia have been statistically associated with the occurrence of bacterial vaginosis (BV) (Ferris et al.
2004; Verstraelen et al.
2004; Bradshaw et al.
2006; Menard et al.
2008; Srinivasan et al.
2012). Despite the high prevalence and burden of BV among women (29% in the United States; Koumans et al.
2007), the causes of this disease remain poorly understood even though women with BV are at higher risk of acquiring sexually transmitted infections and HIV, and preterm birth resulting in low birth weight infants (reviewed in Ma, Forney and Ravel 2012). Besides its link to BV, Atopobium vaginae has also been associated with tuboovarian abscess (Geissdorfer et al.
2003). Genetic differences within Atopobium species may explain why single species can be associated with both health and disease.

The genus Atopobium was first recognized in 1992 and was originally composed of the previously named lactic-acid-producing organisms Lactobacillus minutus, L. rimae and Streptococcus parvulus (Collins and Wallbanks 1992). Studies on these species showed that L. minutus and S. parvulus were each only remotely related to other members of the genus Lactobacillus (Collins et al.
1991) and Peptostreptococcus (Ezaki, Oyaizu and Yabuuchi 1992), respectively. A comparison of the 16S rRNA gene sequences of these organisms showed that they had relatively high sequence similarity amongst themselves (approximately 92–97%), but only low similarity with other species of Lactobacillus and Streptococcus (approximately 79 and 78%, respectively). Phylogenetic analysis showed that these three species constituted a clade that branched from the group of other lactic-acid-producing taxa and it was designated Atopobium by Collins and Wallbanks (1992). A fourth species, A. fossor, which was originally named Eubacterium fossor, has since been added to this genus based upon 16S rRNA sequence and phenotypic similarity to Atopobium (Kageyama, Benno and Nakase 1999).

Our understanding of the human vaginal microbiome has been dramatically increased through the use of culture-independent methods to characterize bacterial diversity that are based on the classification of partial 16S rRNA gene sequences. This has been further enhanced by the development of high-throughput, massively parallel and cost-effective next-generation sequencing technologies that provide the opportunity to obtain detailed surveys of microbial communities. Unfortunately, short 16S rRNA gene sequences obtained using these methods are generally only used for a coarse classification of organisms, usually to the genus level. This has not provided insight into potentially important differences in the whole genome sequences of strains that belong to the same species. However, detailed phylogenetic analysis of these sequences does reveal evolutionary lineages within genera and species (Jonasson, Olofsson and Monstein 2002).

In this study, we describe the taxonomic diversity of species and strains in the genus Atopobium that were found in the vaginal microbiome. To do so, we used samples from previous studies that used either Sanger or Roche 454 pyrosequencing (Zhou et al.
2007, 2009, 2010b; Ravel et al.
2011) of 16S rRNA genes to describe the microbial diversity of the vaginal microbiomes present in asymptomatic, healthy women. Closely related sequences from these studies were matched to those publicly available from the Ribosomal Database Project (RDP; Cole et al.
2009) to classify organisms at the species level. This provided a way to determine whether recognized Atopobium species and currently unknown species of this genus were present in the human vagina. Additionally, we explored the within-species diversity of A. vaginae and report the occurrence of several distinct strain-level clades of this species in vaginal samples.

The 16S rRNA sequences belonging to the genus Atopobium were downloaded from the RDP prior to May 2012 (http://rdp.cme.msu.edu/html; Cole et al.
2009). Only one copy of identical sequences was retained. The final dataset of 311 reference sequences included 26 from cultured strains of recognized Atopobium species (Table 1) and 285 sequences from unknown species and environmental samples that had been identified as Atopobium by the RDP.

infons.section_title_2: Sources of 16S rRNA sequences from vaginal communities

passages.text:
Bacterial sequences from previous studies that characterized the vaginal microbial communities of healthy women were used to create a dataset of sequences belonging to the genus Atopobium. One group of partial 16S rRNA gene sequences had been amplified by PCR from bacterial genomic DNA that had been extracted from vaginal samples and cloned into a plasmid vector (Zhou et al.
2007, 2009, 2010b). The sequences of the V1–V5 regions were then sequenced using the Sanger method yielding 918 bp sequences. A second group of partial 16S rRNA gene sequences also came from bacterial genomic DNA extracted directly from vaginal samples but were amplified using primers specific for the V1–V2 region (240 bp) (Ravel et al.
2011). The sequences of these were generated by Roche 454 pyrosequencing and approximately 2200 reads were obtained from each sample. All of the sequences were classified to the genus level using the RDP naïve Bayesian classifier (Wang et al.
2007) with a default confidence threshold of 80%. Only sequences identified as belonging to the genus Atopobium were retained, yielding 262 sequences from the V1–V5 group and 20 544 from the V1–V2 group.

Sequences in the smaller V1–V5 group were aligned using NAST (DeSantis et al.
2006) and in the V1–V2 group using PyNAST (Caporaso et al.
2010). These alignments were combined together and with the RDP reference sequences after reducing all sequences to the V1–V2 region. The RDP sequences were aligned with the experimental data so that clades resulting from the cluster analysis could be more easily identified as a particular species or strain (Fig. 1). The combined 16S rRNA sequences were grouped at the species level for members of the genus Atopobium and at the strain level for sequences identified as A. vaginae using AbundantOTU+ (v0.93; Ye 2010). A 4% threshold was used to differentiate species-level clades rather than the usual 3% threshold to account for the greater sequence variation inherent in the V1–V2 region (Youssef et al.
2009; Vinje et al.
2014). A 1% threshold was used to differentiate strain-level clades within the species A. vaginae. In order to provide a conservative estimate of diversity, we eliminated clades that contained only one sequence and all clades comprised of sequences from a single individual. Clades that did not include sequences from the reference RDP data set were considered to be novel species- or strain-level clades.

We used 16S rRNA gene sequences from previously published cross-sectional studies to explore the diversity of Atopobium species and strains found in vaginal communities of healthy women. The gene sequences had been generated using either Sanger sequencing of cloned inserts or 454 pyrosequencing, and were assigned to the genus Atopobium using the RDP classifier. These Atopobium sequences, along with reference sequences from the RDP, were clustered together to assess species- and strain-level diversity within this genus.

The original sequences from the V1–V5 group were longer than the sequences from the V1–V2 group, and possibly had a lower incidence of sequencing errors due to the sequencing technology used. In our analysis, we merged the sequences generated using the two sequencing technologies and focused only on the V1–V2 region. However, this was done only after we confirmed that the V1–V2 region from the longer sequences could be used without losing power in the taxonomic assignment of the sequences. Using only the V1–V2 region of the sequences generated using the Sanger technology (V1–V5 group) to simulate the data that would be obtained by pyrosequencing of this region, we ran AbundantOTU+ with a dissimilarity threshold of 4% (Youssef et al.
2009; Vinje et al.
2014). The results matched those obtained on the original V1–V5 analysis in terms of the species- and strain-level clades found (data not shown), indicating that the V1–V2 region alone can be used to distinguish among different clades of the genus Atopobium.

Species-level clades were defined as those that showed at least 96% sequence identity (4% sequence dissimilarity) to a consensus 16S rRNA sequence. Although 97% sequence identity is generally considered to be equivalent to species-level classifications of bacteria (Fox, Wisotzkey and Jurtshuk 1992), the threshold was lowered to 96% identity to account for the greater sequence variation inherent in the V1–V2 region (Youssef et al.
2009; Vinje et al.
2014). As expected, most of the sequences were identified as known Atopobium species with 97% of these being A. vaginae (Table 2). Atopobium parvum, A. minutum and A. rimae, but not A. fossor were also represented at less than 0.1% each. Four novel species had frequencies 10 times greater than these three known species, and another 25 low-frequency species were inferred using our criteria.

The taxonomic diversity of A. vaginae was explored further by forming strain-level clades that showed 99% sequence similarity (1% sequence dissimilarity) to a consensus sequence (Table 2). Over 80% of the sequences were grouped into a clade that includes CCUG 38953, the type strain for A. vaginae (Rodriguez Jovita et al.
1999). Another strain-level clade included 842 sequences (4%) with at least 99% sequence similarity to the strain BVS059, which came from a healthy woman with a grade III microflora (Verhelst et al.
2004) according to the criteria of Ison and Hay (2002). Over 12% of the A. vaginae sequences were grouped together as a novel A. vaginae strain that was not found in the RDP. A total of 21 novel strain-level clades containing more than two sequences, and 24 novel-level clades with two sequences belonging to more than one woman were also inferred in this study. Each sample collected from an individual subject contained sequences belonging to 2.37 strain-level clades of A. vaginae on average (minimum: 1 strain-level clade, maximum: 13 strain-level clades, median: 1 strain-level clade).

In this work, we explored the hypothesis that the members of the genus Atopobium present in the vaginas of healthy reproductive age women have greater species and strain diversity than is usually discerned in studies of vaginal microbial communities. Making use of previously gathered 16S rRNA gene sequence data (Zhou et al.
2007, 2009, 2010b; Ravel et al.
2011), we used sequence identity thresholds of 96 and 99% to create clusters of sequences belonging to the genus Atopobium at the species and strain levels, respectively. This approach allowed us to estimate the number of potentially distinct species and strains that were present in the samples. Our work showed the existence of Atopobium species other than A. vaginae in the vaginas of healthy women. Of the five described species of Atopobium, A. fossor was the only one not found in our samples. In addition to the known species, A. parvulum, A. rimae, A. minutum and A. vaginae, our analysis identified several potential new species-level clades of Atopobium (Table 2). The fact that a higher diversity of Atopobium species was found in our study compared to what was previously known (De Backer et al.
2006) may be explained by the general tendency to focus research efforts on the identification and estimation of abundance of the species of the genus Lactobacillus in the healthy vaginal environment. Other taxa are typically only classified to the genus level and their relative abundances are estimated. As demonstrated by our results, performing analysis with a higher level of scrutiny aimed at identifying all the bacterial species, and the diversity within vaginal species is likely to provide needed insights about the genetic and functional diversity of the vaginal microbiome. Current computational tools such as speciateIT (http://speciateit.sourceforge.net) and pplacer (Matsen, Kodner and Armbrust 2010, https://github.com/matsen/pplacer) have been developed to perform these sorts of analyses.

While our study analyzed sequences exclusively from healthy women, members of the genus Atopobium have also been associated with disease in humans. Aside from the association of A. vaginae with BV, Salimnia et al. (2008) described a candidate Atopobium species that caused sepsis in a woman, while Dewhirst et al. (2001) reported the isolation of a bacterial clone from a patient with acute necrotizing ulcerative gingivitis that was closely related to A. rimae (98% 16S rRNA gene sequence identity). Likewise, Marvaud, Mory and Lambert (2011) isolated a strain of A. parvulum from a tissue infection associated with chronic bedsores, while Kazor et al. (2003) reported that A. parvulum was one of the bacterial species most associated with halitosis. Additionally, Kumar et al. (2003) showed that the more prevalent species or phylotypes in periodontal health include A. rimae and A. parvulum. In contrast, members of the Atopobium group have also been found in fecal samples of three healthy subjects (Rinttila et al.
2004). Furthermore, A. vaginae is commonly found in the vaginas of healthy women (De Backer et al.
2007; Zhou et al.
2007; Ravel et al.
2011). Thus, it is not clear whether or not the species belonging to the genus Atopobium are always causative agents of disease.

Although the isolation of diverse A. vaginae strains from the human vagina was previously reported (De Backer et al.
2006), the level of taxonomic diversity found in our analysis of samples from healthy women suggests that the diversity within this species may be much higher than previously realized, especially when analyses are extended to samples from women with conditions such as BV. This is because we used a conservative estimate of the diversity within the genus Atopobium and within the species A. vaginae. We used sequences from healthy women, and analyzed the genetic diversity observed in a small portion of the 16S rRNA gene, an essential gene that is highly conserved across a wide variety of organisms (Woese 1987). An analysis of the rest of the genome of the organisms identified in our study is bound to yield more genetic diversity, part of which will be reflected as phenotypes that are the target of different selective pressures depending on the environments these organisms experience. A high level of diversity has also been found in another species commonly associated with BV, Gardnerella vaginalis. A comparative analysis of the genomes of 17 strains of this species showed the existence of four subgroups and significant intraspecific genetic diversity. These subgroups were also observed in an analysis using only 16S rRNA gene sequences (Ahmed et al.
2012). Additional analysis of full genomes, including samples from women in different health states, will provide a clearer picture of the diversity in both the Gardnerella and Atopobium, and allow for exploration of whether specific genetic elements, rather than these genera per se, are associated with conditions such as BV.

It is thus possible that the occurrence of disease or an unhealthy condition is associated not specifically with A. vaginae in toto, but with a particular strain or strains, or genetic signatures such as genomic islands (Ogura et al.
2009; Chénais et al.
2012). Genomic islands are composed of clusters of genes conferring different capabilities to organisms, and they tend to be acquired through horizontal gene transfer from plasmids or phages (Hacker and Kaper 2000). This leads to the evolution of pathogenic strains or species from harmless ancestors. Instances of strain-specific genomic islands conferring pathogenic abilities to their hosts (pathogenicity islands) are commonplace and have been found in infections mediated by Escherichia coli (Karch et al.
1999; Hayashi et al.
2001), and Francisella tularensis (Rohmer et al.
2007), for instance. Additionally, a wide variety of species contain pathogenicity islands on their genomes that confer them the ability to infect and exploit both animal and plant hosts. Among these are, for instance, Shigella flexeneri (Jin et al.
2002), Salmonella enterica (Ochman and Groisman 1996; Marcus et al.
2000; Pickard et al.
2003), Yersinia spp. (Carniel, Guilvout and Prentice 1996; Carniel 2001), Legionella pneumonia (Brassinga et al.
2003), Listeria monocytogenes and L. ivanovii (Vazquez-Boland et al.
2001), Staphylococcus aureus (Baba et al.
2007), Clostridium difficile (Baba et al.
2002), Vibrio cholera (Boyd et al.
2000), Pseudomonas syringae (Jackson et al.
1999) and Erwinia amylovora (Oh, Kim and Beer 2005). Furthermore, an analysis of two isolates of G. vaginalis, one from a healthy woman and the other from a woman with BV, showed the existence of differences between the two strains at the genomic and phenotypic level (Harwick et al.
2010). Only a fine description of the genomic diversity in the genus Atopobium will enable us to identify whether particular genotypes, and not species, may cause disease. We suggest that future work focus particularly on the strain-level characterization of A. vaginae as this may prove helpful for fully understanding its function in the vaginal environment and its role in genital health and disease.

We would like to acknowledge the helpful advice from Dr Ye Yuzhen of Indiana University, Bloomington on use of AbundantOTU+. Comments and suggestions from Prof. Steven Witkin from Weill Cornell Medical College, New York, greatly improved the clarity of the manuscript. Computational support was provided by the Computational Resources Core at the Institute for Bioinformatics and Evolutionary Studies at the University of Idaho.
This research was supported by grants U19 AI084044, P30GM103324 from the National Institutes of Health.
Conflict of interest. None declared.
